Hello friends, I'm having some trouble with my notification. Creating the notification and display it is absolutely fine, I've added 3 actions, all with 3 different bundles that communicates with a broadcast receiver and does stuffs based on what action the intent has. My problem is that when I press "pause", I can get values from my bundle passed with that intent (confirmed via toast). Now when I try to start the service again, I'm querying realm to get an object with a specific ID which I get from my bundle. For some reason, the bundle that is tied to the "resume" button does not get passed with that intent. Can anyone explain why? I find this really weird. Code provided below.

I'm in love with Rx
its amazing
I have been practising, and it's finally sinking in..
How do you folks access your app’s sqlite DB in a MVP Architecture properly? I mean on a background thread, not cluttering up the Presenter with LoaderManager code or abusing the View for that?
I just used rx to make my own Places predictions list based on user location and user input, using Rx
so nice
<@U04TK850N> I always just have repository classes which are in charge of anything to do with database operations, and pass an interface into presenter
Presenter then just has `thingyRepository.getStuff()`
Yeah sure, but how do you keep it off the UI thread?
I dont use offline stuff but I would make any database calls in the model and pass that result back to presenter
Oh
I use RxJava for threading
.subscribeOn(<http://Scheduler.io|Scheduler.io>())
`addSubscription(thingRepository.getStuff().subscribeOn(ioScheduler).observeOn(mainScheduler).subscribe(…));`
yep
`addSubscription()` just adds an observable to a composite subscription
Defined in a `BasePresenter` class
compositeSubscription.add( I do this in presenter
and on destroy compositeSubscription.clear()
Yeah same
heh, so time to introduce the others to Rx :smile:
hehe
I know how to do it in Rx, but we don’t have it in the project yet :smile:
:slightly_smiling_face:
Just remember to get them to unsubscribe :joy:
then just offload it to to an async
in the model
and pass back to presenter when done
rule of thumb is keep android class out of Presenter and model
I usually just go for `Observable.fromCallable(() -> methodHere());`

text: in regards to offline first?
Well I might vbe wrong

but the way I understand it is, with offline first you create a model of your app and any data that is to be sent over the network is stored in this model and then at a specificed time its bulk uploaded to the backend

so im not sure how that would contribute to apps being ripped off
well, I was just making sure I had the correct idea about offline first
well it would be much easier to reverse the backend
in that senario

Honestly, do you think it’s easier ripping someone’s APK apart or analysing your network traffic for API endpoints?
id imagine having a secure transport would make that much harder - e.g. https etc
thats a backend issue more than an app-level issue
both are easy
Exactly, so it’s really a non-issue
If you’re arguing for offline first being bad because of security, and online first is just as easy, then it’s really a non-issue
well no, cause with offline how do you deal with stuff that needs immediate attention from the backend

with offline, do you process the data first?
in any situation
before storing

You store it, then access it like you normally would
yes but you must have logic for that in your app
Where it comes from shouldn’t make a difference
If I want to validate inpput in the backend
for security
how do I do that in offline?
depends on the use-case
what u trying to do? if it’s to sign-in? sure, best to ensure a connection is established
if it’s to send a message - you can cache that offline until there’s a connection to submit to a server
lets say that any action the user does be it adding stuff or removing must be validated in the backend
if they send a form over
and then navigate awaway
close the app
and they dont have network
how would I handle that
Put it in a queue
Wait for connection
and when they reopen the app later and they have network I inform them of the error
Sure

again I might be wrong and I will try it out on my next project
to be sure
depends on the priority of the use case - if u need the validation immediately (e.g. making a payment) or it can happen on a delay (e.g. sending a message)

My app is crashing when users upload larger than 16MB images, and I think this is because I try to resize it and it exceeds allowed use of memory for an Android app. What I’ve gathered is that Android apps need to set `android:largeHeap=”true”`in order to use more memory than 16MB. What options are there to deal with this? Not resize? Not allow upload > 16MB? Compress before resize or something?
I wanna learn this Rx Java
How do you resize it?
<https://developer.android.com/reference/android/graphics/BitmapFactory.Options.html#inSampleSize>
you need to use that combined with first reading the size of the image and determining when it would be wise to change the sample size to a value greater than 1
<@U3EQJUNLW> I am using react-native-image-picker so I’m not sure
just keep in mind sample size *must* be a power of 2

as for
>What I’ve gathered is that Android apps need to set `android:largeHeap="true"`in order to use more memory than 16MB.

This is partially true but mostly misleading. Do not use the largeHeap option.
Cool thanks <@U055GGAHS> , I guess I’m going to have to dig into the library code for this one :slightly_smiling_face:
I should never access presenter fields from activity. Right?
No, method calls only

For example I had `presenter.radius`
Using `presenter.getRadius()` doesn’t make a difference and still bad?
In Java, we should expose only methods (and constants) in public APIs.
The question is more about MVP concept
Accessing fields is ~fast~ legal while it is not public API and no code depends on fact that field is exposed.
I wouldn’t personally store any data inside the presenter
I don’t see why you would?
:thinking_face:
So why do you need it then if it empty in your case

For example I need to load user data from network on button click. 

It looks like:
From activity `presenter.loadUser()`
Presenter says to the service `service.loadUser()`
And when it is loaded I call `view.displayUser(user)` from a presenter

So I store User in presenter to be able to do some operations with it for example displaying again without reloading on screen rotation
What is wrong then ?
Why not just store the user in the activity at that point and retain that in `onSaveInstanceState`
Why should I ?
The reason of MVP is to remove logic from the view
So Activity is abstracted from data and only knows how to display it
Ok the example is bad but idea is clear
if you aren't familiar with what mvp is trying to do
My presenters usually stateful and hold some data, but they share their data not via Presenter.field, but via View.showSomething(field)
the reason why you don't want your activity/view knowing anything about the presenter is because the view is hard to test
your presenter simply tells the view what to do
the view shouldn't ever have to ask for anything
<@U08GFT5V5> exactly. This is what i want to confirm
That there is no place for exception
ok so there are some areas that get a little sketchy
even handlers for example
in view you have on click
this delegates to a method in the presenter
TBH I just count the view’s state as part of it’s logic
I delegate, but only passing model objects
A good measure of whether or not you are doing ok is if you can still test your presenter without mocking view components
I don’t think the presenter should know anything about the view’s state
Views should manage their own state imo
The presenter is just a glorified middleman
(in my opinion :stuck_out_tongue: )
My presenters knows something that probably shouldn't but I can't really find another good solution
My view is that I should be able to swap out the view without having to change any state management logic
It knows the R !
So i can do things like: `view.showError(R.string.error_invalid_email);`
I think the actual implementation knowing android specific things is fine
The interface for that would just be `showError(int resId)`
Which is still testable
Exactly
Add annotations for extra confidence and you are fine
yep
`void showError(@StringRes int messageErrorId);`

you can use Observables to get button click notifications in your presenter
make the button Observable in your View and Subscribe in your Presenter

text: gitlab doesn’t impose docker on you but it is an option
I use vagrant with VMs

What is Docker? Docker is aimed to be a helpful convenient tool for simplifying virtual machines/containers creation and managing. Unfortunately it brings much more annoying unexpected traps and problems. Docker is intended to be a pile of lightweight simple tools that rely on existing infrastructure available in operating system, that tries to provide transparent virtualization layer for running dockerized software above it. Actually most software has to be heavily modified to be run under those conditions, dictated by Docker operating environment

Q. Anyone here work with realm?

Q. I have some model classes I already created that are parcelable, can I just extend those models with realmObject and they will work with realm?

Are you looking to send those objects through bundles or so=
Otherwise you can just pass and id, name or so through your bundles and query for the objects when you need them

they will need to be sent to retorfit and converted to JSON
Just add the parcelable stuff that is generated and you're good to go

I do know that RealmLists can't be serialized

(everywhere :stuck_out_tongue: )
haha thanks
don't trust anyone who tells you to use `realm.copyFromRealm()`
except in the context of GSON
Why?
because it's the stupidest thing people can do when they use Realm
haha
okay so there are these people out there who say
"you must keep all reads off the UI thread"
so what they do
is that they grab a Realm on some non-looping background scheduler
and they get their query results from that background thread with `realm.copyFromRealm()`
so now they have two problems:
:laughing:
1.) they have a non-looping background scheduler, which is a thread-pool, so they are most definitely going to experience version retention
2.) they're copying from a database that was designed to have a zero-copy architecture (which is just the fancy name for lazy-loading via these thread-confined proxy objects you get)
I also don't understand people who put managed RealmObjects into Bundles with Parceler.
like, serialize the primary key and requery it, man
why would you do that
ask <@U061HDV96>  he said he does that
seems pointless
i have no idea why you would do that

Anyone here knows how to prevent Realm
from inserting same object?
I don't want duplicates
just add object that doesn't exist
I have a use case that retrieves record from the server
since we don't implement sync for the prototype we just prevent user from adding record when the phone is offline
but the phone has already local records in (that already exist in the server)
there will be time where it will download the data from the server again and as such, my realm throws an error that says that object already exist on Realm
You can always query for the object
And see if it already exists before you perform any logic

Say I want to create a new contact with a provided phone number. I can query the realm for any existing contact with that phone number, if the object returns null, create a new, if it does not, either perform changes or tell the user he can not create a new contact because blablabla
At least that's how I'd do it

*Best audio format to use for short sounds in a app?* 
Hello, im implementing  developing a simple app (This application is developing in both android and iOS) in wich there are buttons associated with short audio files of speeches (30 seconds of maximum duration).my question is, which format we can select for recording and playing in Android?
<@U2LSLN1BM> You can use .wav
or encode it use AAC and store in mp4 for Android and m4a for iOS
<@U0ESBF4AV> thanks!
You are welcome, since wav can be bigger I usually prefer the second one

<@U0ESBF4AV> 

recorder.setAudioSource(MediaRecorder.AudioSource.MIC);
recorder.setOutputFormat(MediaRecorder.OutputFormat.MPEG_4);
recorder.setAudioEncoder(MediaRecorder.AudioEncoder.AAC);
recorder.setAudioEncodingBitRate(?);
recorder.setAudioSamplingRate(?);

im new on media.what about AudioEncodingBitRate and AudioSamplingRate?
I guess you only want to record it for normal use not for 5.1 audio so 128 for bitrate is enough, and for sample rate use 44.1 khz (441000 hz)
Bigger the bitrate better the quality, but your file size will also getting bigger

I am trying to create a chatroom UI and just learned about fragments. What I'm planning to do is have the chatbox fragment display inside the activity scrollview, is this a correct way of doing chatroom UI?
like <fragment>?
maybe what you actually want is to have that scroll view on your Fragment's layout
Fragment can have their own layout
if you want to componentize your UI you can assign fragment to some target FrameLayout (this is what I usually do)
I declare a framelayout tag and programatically place the fragment there via getSupportFragmentManager()
